author: sandra_johnson
content: Hi all, I want to calculate the uncle rate for some block data that I have. How do I calculate the uncle rate? It appears that the number of uncles per block is used in the calculation (is this correct?). With the rate - is that a daily rate, or what is the time period used for calculating the uncle rate? A pointer to where this is defined would be great. I didn't find a reference to uncle or ommer rate in the yellow paper

author: chat-bridge
content: <lithper> I don't think there's a standardized way to calculate it, but I think everyone uses (# uncle blocks)/(# uncle blocks + # main chain blocks)

author: sandra_johnson
content: Thanks ðŸ™‚  What time period is used to calculate this ratio?

author: __lithp__
content: There are no rules, you can use whatever time period you'd like! Your uncle rate will be the rate for that period of time. Is there an uncle rate or something that you're trying to compare your numbers too?

author: sandra_johnson
content: Not really. I am using the data to calculate a probability distribution as input to a model

author: sandra_johnson
content: So I think it is fine if I say how the rate is calculated, and want to make sure that what I use is a fairly standard way of calculating it

author: sandra_johnson
content: The uncle count graph from etherscan.io reports the number of uncles per day, so I think daily rates is probably the way to go.

author: _drinkcoffee
content: I think you could look at the number of uncle header hashes in each blocker header, and do that over a set of blocks. Note that the uncle rate has changed over time

author: sandra_johnson
content: Thanks Peter. How many blocks would you suggest should be in each set?

author: _drinkcoffee
content: How about one day's worth? So 24 X 4 X 60 approximately
